total.title: GHG emissions are changing our climate and choking our world
total.summary: The concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in the earth’s atmosphere is directly linked to average global temperatures and these are rising faster than ever. Right now, we are heading for a catastrophic temperature rise in excess of 3°C this century. To limit global warming to 1.5°C, we need to cut emissions from greenhouse gases —heat-trapping gases that include carbon dioxide, methane, water vapour, nitrous oxide and others— by 30 gigatones annually by 2030. That means cutting emissions from transport and industry, managing land and resources more efficiently, building smart cities and curbing deforestation and food waste.
total.annotation: Each square represents a country, scaled by its emissions

percapita.title: Our individual carbon footprints vary wildly; wealth is a key factor
percapita.summary: The wealthiest 1 per cent of the global population produce more than twice the emissions of the poorest 50 per cent. As developing countries grow their economies, they need financial assistance and technical support to transition to low-carbon, resilient strategies. It is possible to reduce emissions and grow economies. For example the energy sector can cut emissions by 12.5 gigatonnes annually by switching to renewable energy and being more efficient with the power it consumes.

trend.title: Some countries are making progress but all nations need to step up
trend.summary: In 2019, total GHG emissions, including land-use change, reached a new high of 59.1 GtCO2e. This is far above what is needed to achieve the 2015 Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to well below 2°C and pursuing 1.5°C. The good news is that the technologies already exist, including renewable power, green hydrogen and modern bioenergy. The COVID-19 crisis offers a chance to direct recovery measures towards low-carbon, green policies.

surface.title: Rising land temperatures reinforce need for urgent action
surface.summary: The earth’s mean near-surface temperature has risen by more than 1°C compared to the pre-industrial era and, at current rates, this will reach 1.5°C by around 2040 and possibly earlier. To turn this around, we all need to implement lifestyle changes, provide financial and technical assistance for developing nations, and support for nature-based solutions, like reforestation.
surface.short-summary: The earth’s mean near-surface temperature has already risen by more than 1°C compared to the pre-industrial era.

annotation.text: (Country) has seen a (percent/degrees) increase in mean temperatures since (year). The effects include (impacts eg wildfires, heatwaves, etc)

In Madagascar, temperatures have risen significantly (0.2°C over the north and 0.1°C over the south) in recent years. Rainfall patterns have also changed. Between 1980 and 2010, Madagascar was struck by 35 cyclones and floods, five periods of severe droughts, five earthquakes and six epidemics, threatening the uniquely diverse flora and fauna of the island.

In Arctic Siberia, average temperatures reached as high as 10°C above normal for both May and June 2020. Rising temperatures have caused intense wildfires across the region’s boreal forests and tundra. These include “zombie fires” that continue to burn underground and then reignite on the surface. When the tundra, which is a carbon sink, burns it releases more carbon emissions than burning forests.

India has suffered increasingly frequent and extreme heatwaves since the start of the century. A report found the country’s average temperature had risen by 0.7°C from 1901-2018. In 2015, over 2.400 people died in a deadly heatwave and such events have become more common. July 2019 was the hottest July ever recorded.

In the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand, a deadly flood, caused when a glacier broke away and fell into a valley, killed around 140 people in 2021. Data suggests that global warming will cause mountain temperatures to rise twice as fast as the global average. The World Glacier Monitoring Service says that since the 1970s glacial loss has increased rapidly, almost doubling every decade until the present.

Over the last 20 years, California experienced more years of drought than it did without drought. There were droughts between 2001 and 2005, 2007 and 2010, and from 2012 to 2017. These became more intense over time. The most severe period, between January 2014 and January 2017, led to a severe water deficit in both the soil and underground aquifers.

The northernmost inhabited Arctic town, Longyearbyen on the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard, saw a new record temperature of 21.7°C on 25 July 2020, compared to July average of 5.9°C, according to Norway's national meteorological service.

ocean.title: Our oceans are getting warmer and sea levels are rising
ocean.summary: Ice sheets and glaciers are melting, pushing sea levels higher and threatening coastal cities and settlements. Rising sea levels mean storm surges will be deadlier. Carbon dioxide emissions also lead to ocean acidification, which harms marine species, including corals. And things could get worse: as the world gets hotter, it is more likely the Arctic will be ice-free in summer, further disrupting ocean circulation and ecosystems.
ocean.short-summary: Ice sheets and glaciers are melting, pusing sea levels higher and threatening coastal cities and settlements.

annotation.text: (Name of ocean/sea) has seen a (percent/degrees) increase in surface temperatures since (year). Ocean warming can cause coral bleaching and loss of breeding grounds for fish and mammals.

In September 2020, Arctic sea ice shrank to the second-lowest extent ever recorded (3.709 million square kilometres). Also last July, the area of Arctic sea ice was the lowest on record for that month. A Siberian heatwave accelerated the ice retreat along the Arctic Russian coast, in particular from late June.

In March 2020, Australia’s Great Barrier Reef suffered a third mass coral bleaching event in five years due to increasingly warmer temperatures recorded in February. To date the Reef, home to the world’s largest collection of coral reefs, has suffered six mass bleaching events due to warmer than normal ocean temperatures: in 1998, 2002, 2006, 2016, 2017 and 2020.

fire.title: Wildfires raise spectre of terrifying new normal in hotter world
fire.summary: Huge wildfires in Australia, the Amazon, California, the Congo basin and even in the Arctic are sobering reminders of the human, economic and environmental costs of climate change. Record temperatures, heatwaves and droughts help spark wildfires. The global average temperature is now around 1.1°C higher than at the beginning of last century, meaning wildfires and megafires could become a new normal in some countries.
fire.short-summary: Wildfires in Australia, the Amazon, California, or the Congo basin are sobering reminders of costs of climate change.

annotation.text: In (country), wildfires typically strike in (months/season). In (recent year), wildfires (insert consequences in terms of lives lost, acreage lost, species lost).

In Australia, the 2019-2020 wildfire season was the worst on record, burning 18.3 million hectares by mid-January, causing loss of life, homes, livelihoods and the reported deaths of a billion animals. Australia’s wildfire season coincides with its summer, which runs from December to February, with fires typically peaking in late January or early February.

In the western United States, following record-breaking high temperatures in August 2020, lightning strikes from severe thunderstorms ignited fires in California, Oregon and Washington. By the end of September, these blazes had consumed over 2 million hectares across the three states, destroyed over 7,000 structures and left at least 40 people dead.

In Arctic Siberia, exceptional and prolonged heat fuelled unprecedented fires during the summer of 2020. Temperatures were more than 5°C above average from January to June, and in June up to 10°C above average. Satellite images from Europe's Sentinel 3 showed that the wildfires covered a width of about 800 kilometers.

In 2015, massive wildfires ravaged Indonesia, scorching 2.6 million hectares and producing a toxic haze that blanketed neighboring Singapore and Malaysia. Thousands fell ill, and the Indonesian government suffered $16 billion in economic losses, according to the World Bank. Fires set to clear land often spiral out of control, particularly during the dry season, roughly from June to October.

Canada suffered the worst wildfire season on record in 2018, with 16,000 people evacuated as 2,117 wildfires filled the skies of western Canada with smoke. Weather was a key driver with late July bringing record-breaking temperatures and severe lightning storms to many areas. More than 70,000 lightning strikes were registered between July 31 and August 1, followed by another extreme lightning event on August 11.

In 2020, Brazil’s Amazon rainforest experienced its worst outbreak of fires in a decade, with blazes increasing 13 per cent in the first nine months compared to 2019. Satellites in September recorded 32,017 hotspots, a 61 per cent rise from the same month in 2019. Scientists said the 2020 dry season was more severe than the previous year, partly because of warming in the tropical North Atlantic Ocean pulling moisture away from South America.

ndcs.title: Countries must strengthen pledges made under Paris Agreement
ndcs.summary: In 2015, nations made pledges, known as Nationally Determined Contributions, to reduce emissions. These must now be revised upwards if we are to achieve the Paris Agreement goals. So far, 126 countries, covering 51 per cent of global emissions, have adopted, announced or are considering net-zero goals. A green recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic could help but if we want to avoid disaster, the levels of ambition in the Paris Agreement must be roughly tripled for the 2°C pathway and increased at least fivefold for the 1.5°C pathway.

public.title: Public awareness and concern must catalyze political action
public.summary: Public concern over climate change is rising. In a survey of 26 nations in 2018, the Pew Research Center found that people broadly agree that climate change poses a severe risk to their countries, with populations in 13 nations seeing climate change as the top international threat. However, so far this awareness has not translated into sustained political action on a global scale. This must change.
